job_title: Clinical Research Specialist in Durham, NC
pros: Understanding environment, I had health issues go on during my last few months and study staff / my direct superiors was extremely helpful. The job offers flexible hours, positive work environment for the most part. Seeing and working with patients was my favorite part of the job.
cons: Spend a lot of hours by yourself, and staring at screens, I had the option to work remotely but the remote desk top would crash and a lto of times would not save work. I would have to go into the office whenever patient are in clinic or available (sometime on a Sunday), it isn't expected to do this but was needed to be done in order to meet the quarterly recruitment goal and have reliable data that was time sensitive. PI's do not understand the job or the details of the study which can sometimes be problematic for study staff. It can cause confusion and stress and waste time trying to explain the study to a PI in a respectful manner. My PI could be moody and unpredictable, but I do not think that is norm from other research staff I have spoken to. All and all though, the company and the job is wonderful for an entry level position.

review_title: Duke is at Risk with the current Vice President , Procurement and Supply Chain Leader
pros: Duke University and Duke University Health System Enterprise is a good place to work and going thru a transformation!
cons: Duke University and Duke University Health System Enterprise are at Risk with the current Vice President , Procurement and Supply Chain Leader holding this position today in 2023. He is very disrespectful, drives favoritism, and makes life very difficult for the people he does not like, especially within his organization today. He uses his empowerment and title to his advantage and leadership/Human Resource is doing nothing about it to correct his behavior because he is driving huge savings for the organization. He is only promoting and giving merit increases to the people he likes. He has created a hostile environment within the Procurement and Supply Chain organization in almost 2 years being here and Executive Leadership is doing nothing about it to address it. He is using a very elegant tactic approach to discriminate and retaliate against the people he does not like with the hope they leave and several of the associates that left have been with Duke for 10-15-20-15 years (WOW). How can Duke Enterprise , a very respectful organization globally, allow such a person to damage the Duke Procurement and Supply Chain Organization this way for almost two years? We understand he is giving you Millions of dollars in savings but he is doing it in a way where the mental health of the people in this organization is deteriorating and are afraid to speak up. He is a dangerous person and needs to be removed ASAP.

review_title: Good spot to work, but CRC work is underpaid
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Durham, NC
pros: Duke has some good benefits, particularly in regards to how they give PTO. As Duke is a large organization with multiple clinical research departments and teams, it is not too difficult to move around to find where you fit best!
cons: Clinical Research Coordinators are in short supply, and this may in large part be due to salary - Duke can rarely match salaries of other Clinical Research positions in RTP. Likewise, your work environment may vary wildly depending on what team you are working with, which is an incentive to stay for some teams and a red flag for others. At the time of this review, there are several Duke CRUs with CRC vacancies - even in my own team CRC positions have gone unfilled for about 6 months. In that time management has updated the team about multiple applicants who passed all interview rounds only to turn the position down due to low pay. In the meantime, much of the work from these vacancies is often divided among the remaining staff.

pros: Great health benefits and generous vacation/sick/PTO. Everything is very streamlined and easy to manage. After five years of service you are eligible for the Children's Tuition Grant. HUGE benefit! The people at Duke are all very down to earth and enjoy their work which makes it a pleasurable experience. There are a lot of fringe benefits as well such as use of athletic facilities and employee discounts. In general, supervisors are understanding and genuinely care about their employees.
cons: Working remotely is discouraged by some schools/ offices. They will allow you to work remote two days a week but will take your office away if you do not work at least four days in the office. They pay lower than other local universities (however Duke does have better benefits) There isn't a lot of transparency from the top down when it comes to decision making.

review_title: No promotions for single women of color
pros: Tuition benefit for employees; but taking classes requires supervisor approval. * limits the kinds of degrees you can go for and the classes you can take.
cons:
- Do the work of your colleagues when they go on maternity leave; when they come back, they get the promotion (and you won't). 

- Old (white) boys club; but the white women who have learned from the patriarchal systems of power, reinforce the system, instead of working to make it more inclusive. 

- It is not uncommon - rather the norm - for women of color to wait for many years (to decades) to advance. When I asked for a bump in title (after 5 years, then again after 8 years) I was lectured on 'paying my dues' by a white male boss.

-It is not worth it. Eventually, the minorities who can, will leave. Only for a new minorities to come in, get lowballed in salary and say thank you. The Duke reputation is closely guarded and protected, but do yourself a favor and if you have any ambition left, go somewhere else.

pros: I've loved working at Duke. They've been incredibly supportive during the pandemic. Employee health and welfare have clearly been a priority from the top management, all the way down the chain. Although the university suffered severe financial consequences from the pandemic, they were proactive and thoughtful about reaching out to employees with personal message of recognition and gratitude for the work we've done to support students. Thankfully, leaders prioritized employees and implemented strategic initiatives to avoid layoffs.
cons: Real progress on diversity and inclusion are slow going, despite leadership's statements and efforts in support of these ideals. Representation of women and ethnic and religious minorities in faculty are not where they should be. It can be difficult to grow in your career if you stay at Duke, which is unfortunate. High quality contributors can languish in positions unless they leave for peer institutions.

review_title: Great starter job for someone interested in retail.
pros:
This is a great place to work at. The co-workers, management, and clientele are for the most part, amazing people. It truly is a pleasant community as long as you are well-behaved and aware of others' needs. 

The store itself is beautifully laid out and although mainly selling high-end products, there are promotional offers and sales on a frequent basis. 

Duke Campus is gorgeous and adjacent facilities are worth visiting.
cons:
Temporary workers hired through staffing agencies are short-changed from the benefits that Duke employees enjoy, despite doing the same type and amount of work, sometimes more. It is very disheartening for a committed "temporary" worker to be paid significantly less than her co-workers despite sharing the same responsibilities. 

The constant change in shifts brings conflicts to employee's stability. The hours and days change on a bi-weekly basis. Lunch and break hours also seem to change also on a daily basis, which makes for unhealthy eating and resting habits. 

Lastly, although very understandable, the activities that take place in this store are subject to the many activities that take place in the university, particularly when it regards Alumni and Athletes. This complicates further trying to plan ahead your personal life. 

Parking in this university is a nightmare.

pros: Consistent entertainment from clients and colleagues is a major pro for the position. You are charged with producing a lot of creative events and often times, you and the team contribute greatly to making these events fun for everyone. The clients, the Tipsters, are great and entertaining as each of them show their personality and individuality. To assist with a lot of administrative, and physical work RCs do, the organization does provide high quality resources.
cons:
Not much staff bonding time. A lot happens in the course of three weeks, and often times the organization is pressured to do a lot. 

Communication has been improving each year for the staff overall, however individual communications between teams and groups vary. Most of residential staff had been communicating via groupme, which has helped but also has made information easy to lose as the app is consistently flooded by staff's posts. 

Each year, I have applied for higher paying positions, and positions of higher leadership, and unfortunately had little room for advancement. 

Aside from that and personality issues, there had been a perceived lack in diversity in the past four years I've worked on East Campus in both staff and students.

pros:
Flexible hours. Responsive shift scheduling software. Contact info database for all fellow employees made it easy to contact people for shift swaps. Half of every shift is time for you to do homework or other low-key desk work while you're not in the lifeguard stand. 

Duke provides for your re certification every year or so to keep you up to the current red cross life guard training qualifications. This saves you a lot of money for recert classes and testing.
cons:
Some coworkers can be annoying. This isn't really specific to this position, since you can have difficult coworkers in every job, but some of the Duke University faculty can be really entitled and rude when they come to use the facilities. 

There also are a lot of pointless liability rules to enforce. The number of waivers you have to ask people to sign is a little outrageous. Though the lifeguards were not in charge of the decision to introduce this new paperwork, we have to enforce it and ask people to fill it out, and we are consequently on the receiving end of any ire over this annoyance.

pros: The kids are whip smart and a joy to work with, and the topics are fascinating and easy to teach. The residential activities are also a lot of fun.

Though both positions are fun and interesting, the schedule can be overwhelming and confusing for new staff, and cause mistakes for which there will be disciplinary action.

review_title: Flexible, engaging, yet just as bureaucratic as public institutions.
job_title: Postbac Research Affiliate in Durham, NC
pros:
-Pay is good and raises given usually after a semester or two.
-So much interesting research! It's exciting going to work.
-Extremely flexible with part-time schedules.
-Diverse and (usually) intelligent co-workers.
-Beautiful campus and weather, especially from mid-Sept to mid-May.
cons:
-Moving within from student part-time to anything else is nearly impossible, I got lucky. Duke hates it when recent grads stay. They want us flying all over the world saving humanity, since obviously we all can afford it. I only have a few months left and contacting other labs in this department for work is a joke. They don't give you the time of day. At least I get a nice automated email from industry or USAJobs. Here, silence from almost everyone.
-As usual for universities, greed is rampant. Parking is awful (though not monitored on weekends), housing and food are grossly overpriced, and there are charges for everything in between.
-My co-workers and employers are pleasant, but the University as a whole has a slightly arrogant vibe. Until maybe a decade or two ago this was justified, but in this economy, the only difference between a Duke degree and a public school one is that you're an extra ~150k in the hole.
-Durham is better than in past years, but is still in many ways a crime-ridden pustule of Raleigh.

pros: Working with the best and the brightest
cons: The city is not for everyone

pros: Great place to work and loved the environment.
cons: Low salary, less opportunity within the institute at the faculty level.

pros: At Duke Divinity School I used management consulting skills to support efforts in hospice and post-war reconciliation. Fabulous worthy work at the top of many faith-based organizations. You learn a lot about why people act the way they do and what worthy goals are, and you get to hang out with people who have read many of the best ancient texts. The subject matter is inspirational and fascinating. I learned so much!
cons: There is a naivety in top-tier universities about management. In my experience, it goes like this: "Because X is a prestigious university, and X hired me, I must be great at my supervisory role too though I have little management training, nor does my supervisor, and we do not have any role models for what a great manager does or looks like except for (fill in name of top sports coach like Coach K), who we invoke, but don't emulate." In this region, I have experienced this situation at UNC and at Duke. I love both the universities campuses and a lot of people on each campus. But this is a real problem leading to very painful public issues for both institutions that harm the institutions.

review_title: Great benefits, poor pay, big egos - work environment varies widely
pros: The benefits (403(b), medical coverage, business discounts and tuition help, to name a few) are outstanding. The campus is beautiful and convenient to commuters. Job security appears to be good.
cons: Pay is poor for non-faculty - it looks good on paper if you factor in benefits, but is lousy if you need liquidity. Work-life balance, office environment and many other factors are highly dependent on which unit you're in and who you work for. Egos are out of control - faculty "stars" are put in charge of staff with little guidance on management and no motivation to gain any, and grudges between higher-level faculty/staff can really hamstring others. Academic/meeting-heavy culture means it can take forever to get things done. Promises at hiring of potential movement/promotion within the university have not been kept (for me or others).

pros: Good benefits and very steady work cycle... if this is what you're looking for. If you are hired at management level or above, you may have more flexibility, but anything below that places you in the middle or bottom of a huge, bureaucratic system that discourages any kind of change.
cons: There are a lot of cons in this position and specifically regarding the culture at Duke, generally. Encouraged to sit at your desk from 9-5 even if you only have a few hours of work. Wastes human resources and discourages anyone with talent from becoming better or pursuing more responsibility. Please keep in mind I'm speaking specifically about my experience as a staff person at one of Duke's professional schools. Mid-level management is a huge road block and ethically speaking, treats direct reports with disrespect. In my position there has been lots of turnover-- a new person each year for the past 4 or 5 years. You would think this sends a signal, but surprisingly, it hasn't yet. Fundraising is beholden to big donors, even at the expense of the University's mission of educating students. Overall, I would never recommend this working environment to anyone.

review_title: My experience at Duke was a positive one.
job_title: Revenue Integrity Analyst in Durham, NC
pros: Duke has some very good people to work with. They genuinely care about their job and the patient's they care for. Everyone generally goes out of their way to ensure the patient safety goals are met and that they hold true to their mission and vision.
cons: As much as Duke tries to hold true to their mission and vision as an organization overall there are some shortfalls within the leadership (i.e., managers) structure. Managers are not always supportive of employees and issues they face, and policies are not always distributed fairly across the board. Thereby, leading to tension and dissension amongst employees who witness the discrimination. Too many cases have arisen as a result of poor judgment, indecision, and unfair application of policies, leading to unfair treatment and/or loss of a job.

review_title: great place if you're faculty, not so much if you're staff
pros: Great benefits, flexibility depending on which department you work in, tuition benefits, job security, chances to transfer to other positions
cons: employees are not paid what they are worth; combining too many jobs into one; staff know they are not valued and are viewed as easily replaceable and for cheaper; low morale; often have to leave your department to receive a promotion; because of the hierarchical management structure, those who can implement changes have no idea how bad it really is for staff because those that report to them are not reporting the truth; positions need to be reclassified because a lot of people are listed as staff assistants when they should at least be admin assistants

pros: Good place for mid/late-career folks who want a place to 'settle in'. If you are ambitious, and just starting your career- look elsewhere.
cons:
• old *white* boys club, no upward mobility- especially for minorities, many managers have never supervised before and resort to micro-managing, (*There are some good managers and teams, but it doesn't exist in every department*)

• nepotism, favoritism

• starting salaries are low-balled because 'our benefits are worth $20K -$30K'. (They are not that great and depending on your age, you may not use all of them.)

• Advocating for 'diversity' in theory, but not in practice. For a prestigious institution *which works on its public image*, there are significant microagressions and insensitivities in various departments. Over time they build up, and good people feel powerless and leave. HR/administration is not supportive and protects incompetence in higher ranks.

job_title: Research Program Leader in Durham, NC
pros: Retirement and Health Benefits are excellent. Pay at the time of hire is good in my field.  Good people in most of the groups I have worked with. Work life balance is good.
cons:
Salary setting formulas aren't always fair and you can't really talk to anyone about it.  HR uses a formula and only a really good manager in a department without roadblocks can go to bat for you. Duke is not about transparency with pay at all. I get paid 5-10% less than two of my coworkers who the same level of education and the same amount of expereince.  Honestly, I have more experience with management, But my department or Duke won't coun it because I managed employees in a different field... as if personnel management skills are not transferable. 

Also, once you get hired into Duke, raises are hard to come by and the annual increase is like 2%, so people leave and come back to adequate raises commensurate with experience. 

Education benefits for employees are not great compared to those at State Universities in NC.

pros:
I've worked a few summer camp-type jobs, and Duke TIP has the best hours, accommodations, and pay. I also really enjoyed working with brilliant people. (both the kids and the staff). You'll work hard for the time you are there, but it's a whole lot of fun! The budget is also very generous for classroom supplies. 

It's a great gig for anyone who wants some teaching experience.
cons:
Expect long days -- that's the nature of this type of job. Also expect the administrative team on site to vary from summer to summer, thus creating changes in staff culture each year. Some of upper level staff are better than others. Also, discipline can be challenging.

It can be a difficult gig for anyone who is a more "seasoned" professional and is used to a more 9-5 schedule or just teaching 2-3 classes a week at a university.

review_title: Duke was a great place to work for entry-level positions in science.
pros: Salaries were competitive; benefits were great; atmosphere was top-notch, intellectually and socially. The people I worked with at Duke were friendly, intelligent, and team-oriented. Buildings/workspaces were amazing. And there is a newish library next to the medical center now. This affords some great workspace whenever you need to write or prepare a presentation. Projects were state-of-the-art. Seminars on campus drew top-notch researchers. Studies being published in labs at Duke are cutting edge....lots of leaders in each field. And there are great fitness centers on campus - a kick-butt cross country trail, etc. So you can go for a great run over lunch. Overall, it's just a great place to be.
cons: Parking was a pain, and the labs were small in some cases: very few people in each lab, working under each P.I. P.I.s had some in-fighting, at times, which made things awkward. The younger P.I.s treated the place like it was a pressure cooker at times. But they pulled in great grants. So I guess it balanced out.

review_title: You may want to consider other job options
pros: Executive Director is eager and excited to build new partnerships and increase diversity. Downtown Durham location is nice and building is beautiful. Some of the Duke benefits are competitive (ex: employer contributions, Duke medical care options, generous tuition grants for your kids after 5 years of employment)
cons: Bullying and micromanagement from some senior staff. Hostile work environment with no work-life balance.  Almost everyone is overworked and underpaid. Senior management rarely communicates to staff and your job is subject to change daily so you aren't doing the job you were hired to do.  Highly qualified internal staff who applybfor internal positions are often overlooked for new external applicants. Extremely high staff turnover, especially on the Educational Programs team. Salaries are terrible unless you are a Director or lead a department.  Staff morale is low and almost everyone who hasn't already left TIP is looking for employment elsewhere.

pros: Lots of smart people, great benefits, tremendous research university, excellent network.  Alumni love the school and largely make themselves available for networking.
cons: Poor management; low salary; outstanding performance does not translate to higher compensation or career advancement; strange colleagues.  Higher education is generally an industry where people who may not function all that well in the private sector can find a niche.  That is to be expected, but you would hope that the people in management and executive roles would have some degree of self-awareness and some social skills.  There is a sense that they are doing the employee a favor by allowing them to work for Duke -- despite the fact that Duke pays less than other Universities, even those in the local area where the cost of living should be relatively equivalent.

pros: Great HR assistance with parking/ID card/scheduling. The professor was great as well as the students in the lab and the support staff was very timely and helpful if you ever needed to submit a work order. I never really had any interaction with CEO level personnel but if you had a favorable review every year they were good at giving you their raise and networking within the University system was priceless.
cons: Parking was complicated and expensive if you had to commute to work with your car and you have to remember that even if you fulfill your hours you still have to touch base with your PI on their hours to complete your projects.

review_title: Not Family Oriented / Discrimination in Workplace
pros: Working from home was a plus since I was part-time
cons: I was laid off 1 month before maternity leave from DUSON after being treated poorly by my bosses once they found out I was pregnant. They told me I was expected me to return 2 weeks after having my baby and practically begged me to let them hire someone else and reduce my part-time hours since I would be going on Maternity leave. I went to HR about it and still ended up getting laid off with another employee replacing me before my last day and them saying the grant will not pay for my position anymore which was a complete lie. This place has so much work to do and does not hold up to its reputation in my opinion. Do not waste your time here, it's not a workplace to invest in for long term.

review_title: Stable, low stress job, but few opportunities for advancement
job_title: Comparative Medicine Specialist I in Durham, NC
pros:
Nice to have the name on your resume
Direct supervisor is excellent, very nice to work for
Very laid back and low stress
Friendly atmosphere
Very much freedom to complete your work as you wish throughout the week
cons:
Upper management is reactionary, rules are not implemented until a negative situation arises
Promotions and upward movement is almost impossible
Management is disconnected with employees, I don't even know most of them, and rules and standard operating procedures are implemented by these people...when they don't actually do the jobs they are changing the rules for
Even though we are the most important employees in the department, we are at the bottom of the totem pole
If you complain, there have been accounts of "Well McDonald's is hiring" being said to employees

pros:
1. Duke is a prestigious university with a great reputation. 
2. Access to the best resources and tools for doing cutting edge research. 
3. Funding is always an issue, but being at Duke helps significantly when applying for fellowships and grants. 
4. The training programs at Duke are designed well to provide the structures for attaining an excellent education. 
5. The stipend is very competitive and stretches a long way in a relatively inexpensive area to live.
cons:
1. The benefits (especially health) aren't amazing, especially compared with those at some public institutions around the country. 
2. The parking/transportation is also not great, especially for first-year students, who are the lowest on the priority list for premium parking spots. Having a car is almost essential if you want to experience the Triangle area fully.

pros: Excellent health benefits; great facilities; beautiful campus; staff, undergrads, grad, an professional students all interact with due to shared proximity on campus.
cons: Can be downside to working with some faculty st time. Parking is really tough- may need to walk a bit or catch a shuttle from parking lot. Upper level management can be driven heavily by bonuses. Culture is the same as most academic medical centers in the sense that a lot is to be expected workwise - as you move up through ranks can feel like you are doing the work of 2 or 3 people or more at times. Not too much negative beyond that.

review_title: Lots of Resources but weird policies
pros: You get that name on your CV or resume.  Duke isn't an Ivy but it is right in the tier below so if you are on an academic track it stands out, maybe even more than the quality would warrant.   There are a lot of resources on campus to help you find your next position on the academic track.  Lots of companies come to campus to recruit.
cons: Weirdly insular culture.  They have their way of doing things and aren't interested in more general standards.  For example, academic trainees, such as postdocs and grad students, are required to fill out time cards in some departments.  I haven't ever heard of that practice in any other institution.  There is also much less collaboration and socialization with coworkers here than I am used to in other academic settings.  It ends up feeling very corporate.

review_title: a fun summer camp experience for those who want to teach
pros: The atmosphere is very relaxed and fun-oriented. It's a summer camp, after all! It's also an excellent litmus test for people considering entering education -- if you find yourself enjoying seeing your kids grow intellectually and discovering an appreciation for the field you're so passionate about, you would probably make a great teacher.
cons: Pay is low for the hours you have to put in, and you'll be living in a dorm near the kids, but housing and food are free, so it's not that bad.

pros: Good 401k Matching plan.
cons: In some ways the Bioinformatician position at Duke, especially in the core facilities, combines the most unpleasant aspects of both industry jobs and academia. One on hand, you have all the structure of Industry including closely watched arrival and departure times, extensive monitoring of computer and internet use, numerous meetings every day, close monitoring of email and web calendar is required. On the other hand, you have all the difficult prima-donna-type personalities of academics. For a recent graduate looking for a first job consider a startup instead: probably better pay, friendlier colleagues, and experience that will make you more attractive for your next  position. Lastly, monitoring announcements for these positions, you will see some groups at Duke who seem to always have a new positions. Hint: these are not new positions, they are positions were that last person just left or was fired. So careful with those groups.

job_title: Associate In Research in Durham, NC
pros: Treated very well, the pay and benefits have been fair, I am trusted to come and go as I please provided I get the job done.  I get my own office with solid hardware/software (Linux computers!) that I can personalize so long as its safe for work materials.
cons: In my case, the job is intrinsically temporary and the feeling of dead-end makes caring difficult.  Not really a fault of the company per se, but makes work less enjoyable.  Also the trust can be a bit extreme, to the point where I am frequently alone in my office with minimal/no collaboration.  Since I wish to be an engineer in the long run (ie teamwork and problem-solving), this makes it hard to feel engaged or like my work matters.

review_title: Good Biomedical Engineering Program, Great Place to Live
pros: The BME department is globally top-tier, and making good investments in adding strength in the molecular/synthetic biology areas to add to their traditional instrumentation and imaging strengths. Funding, resources, core facilities, and neighboring universities mean you will likely have access to any equipment or opportunities you need. The career counseling services are actually quite good, and classes are generally helpful though many are required. Finally, Durham is a great place to live for many types of people. Lots of outdoors and cultural activities for a town of its size, mountains and coast in range for weekend trips, and extremely livable stipend vs. cost of living, especially compared to peer programs in big cities. Many grad students are able to buy houses in the area and have a good quality of life.
cons: Coursework requirements in the BME program are significantly higher than at peer programs.

job_title: Associate In Research in Durham, NC
pros:
- Extremely flexible work schedule. 
- Good benefits.
For engineering:
- Decent diversity.
- State of the art equipment.
- Minimal annual required training.
- Excellent principal investigators.
cons: As with any company, the job depends quite a bit on the group dynamic and management. I worked in a very practical, friendly, enthusiastic group that made my experience great. The PI I worked for very actively ensured that his people were taken care of and had limited hurdles to perform their work.

review_title: It's who you know, not what you can do...
pros: Benefits are pretty good. Tuition reimbursement is good too.
cons: There are a lot of cliques in this place and a lot of special treatment. It doesn't matter how good you are at your job you only move up if you know someone or are in one of these cliques. There is also a lot of prejudice going on. Oh and this place is only family friendly to the people in these cliques and the higher ups.

review_title: Postdocs are second-class citizen at Duke medicine.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Durham, NC
pros: Good facilities, great cores, smart students, OK salary and insurance no retirement.
cons: Do not work for MDs that do not have R01s, they most likely do not have the scientific expertise to advise you and have a big ego. My PI have insulted team members including me multiple times at lab meetings when he is not happy or scientifically challenged. MD PIs only let MD fellows go to conferences, and ignore that PhD postdoc need to go to conferences to connect and network also. PhD postdocs are treated like slaves. The worth thing is some PIs will take an extra step and block your career advancement to keep you here to work for them, very selfish.

pros: Good work-life balance, good benefits, great staff, relaxed environment.
cons: Staff jobs are either "churn-and-burn," where multiple job positions (and responsibilities) are rolled into a single position resulting in high stress and low support, or jobs are "feast-and-famine," where there are long stretches of not having anything to do and then a glut of work.  I'm currently in a Trinity A&S department that is the latter.  Compensation skews low but benefits do make up for this partially.

review_title: A fantastic place to spend your mid-20s
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Duke treats its engineering graduate students exceptionally well. A reasonable paycheck is more than enough to support oneself in the triangle, and the department exudes an honest concern for the well-being of its students. Engaged administration, from the Deans down to the administrative assistants, are eager to help with issues from feedback on the direction of the school the mundane day-to-day paperwork. With many well-funded PI's, funding is rarely (though occasionally) a concern for the students. The resources and opportunities available to students at little to no cost create a tremendous value-add, whether it is free concerts or professional development programs aimed at PhD candidates interested in nonacademic careers.
cons: The day-to-day culture is highly dependent on the character of the PI, so be aware that some PIs may be less lenient with schedules and vacations than others.

pros: Good benefits and a diversity of job opportunities. Some offices have an excellent work culture. If you land in one of these, you can be very happy.
cons: Duke is the very model of the trend in American work culture towards endlessly increasing productivity by normalizing overwork. If you have a young family, value your personal life, and especially if you have any mental health issues, working at Duke can make you miserable if you don’t find the right supervisor or office culture. This is especially true working from home while caring for children during a pandemic.

review_title: Duke is a good summer option as a freshman/sophomore.
pros: It provides a great look into what research is like and also helps you avoid the nasty summer job search if you want to put that off one more year.  All of the research opportunities are interesting and will definitely get you noticed by technical employers if that's what you're looking into.  After going through a lot of interviews as a junior I've referenced my work at Duke over the summer countless times, and it looks great because it really is independent work.
cons: You miss out on the experience of working in industry.  Also, Duke is relaxing in the summer, but at the same time you'll probably start getting bored towards the end.

pros: Better pay and benefits than UNC for same job.  Some departments have comfortable work environment.
cons: Can only speak for unit where I work, but if you need a flat organizational structure and can't/don't want to adapt to a more hierarchical structure, I'd suggest looking somewhere else. Quality of work environment really depends on specific manager, although I hear some units have dysfunctional top level management where not even a good mid-level manager can maintain a good work environment (and probably doesn't stick around).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Duke is a wonderful place to work. The environment is challenging and invigorating, yet supportive. The ability to take courses in any school or department as a PhD student is fantastic, especially if you are considering employment outside your specific research area.
cons: As a graduate student in engineering, it's not the best place if you want to gain a lot of valuable teaching experience. They are training researchers, not instructors. Also, it's a shame that the benefits package does not include true vision or dental insurance.

pros: Career opportunities within department and with other departments, employee benefits including children's college tuition is important after working for Duke for > five years and overall job security as Duke has kept staff reductions to a minimum.   Duke does some amazing research and the benefit of working with some great scientists and visionaries
cons: As an academic organization, there are strong politics and many personal agendas.  Good business decisions are often challenging (to make let alone implement) and often driven by faculty input, needs or expectations.

pros: Great place to work.  Friendly people and atmosphere, good balance between family life and work life, enough people to get the job done without stressing you out to the max.  Great health benefits and occasional other neat perks as well, like football or basketball game tickets.
cons: The pay is not that great, but better than public universities.  This is a given though.  The raises aren't that great either.  In my particular department, there was no room to move up, so I was pretty much stuck.  It's also a very liberal, politically-motivated environment.

review_title: All in all a good experience during the first three years. Management changes after that hurt the team.
pros: Benefits are really good and working on a campus was a plus. The environment was clean, easy to maneuver in and safe.
cons: The pay rate could have been better. Management spends too much time covering themselves, blaming the staff for anything and everything. Praise for a good job goes a long way. Long term, talented people that are dedicated were not appreciated as much as short term employees going through the motions. A shame that management changed, it used to be a great place to be.

review_title: All the resources at your disposal.
pros: Reputation, tremendous resources, ability to do interesting cross disciplinary work. There are endless possibilities. I really liked the fact that, at Duke, people were always making connections across departments. There are lots of university wide programs, and lots of opportunities to do your own thing. I had a friend who got a small grant to interview all sorts of professors about the use of technology in the classroom. He had a great time with that. The Duke brand, though somewhat tarnished in the past few years, is still strong, and will only get better as time passes. It certainly has opened doors for me.
cons: Disconnected from reality (academia), Durham isn't the greatest place to spend time.

review_title: I think the Duke Raleigh has good people, but lousy options for being such a small place and a Duke Entity.
pros: I like working with Duke for its flexible schedules, great benefits and nice people. I did like my position where I did not feel micromanaged and I had options to have different shifts in different portions of the hospital.
cons: I do not feel that learning and/or job improvement  was a strong asset for this company. In my previous job position, I felt like I was stuck and the one of two ways that I found to move forward were not applicable to me. I also feel that because this was a smaller hospital, the resources were limited, which can be a factor when considering.

pros: Good benefits, capable staff, and a beautiful campus are all reasons to like working here. When times got bad during the recession, Duke didn't furlough or cut anybody, just froze our salaries for a few years.
cons: Parking and childcare are both expensive at Duke, and are both hard to get into. I've known folks who had to wait three years to get a preferred lot, or into daycare. With the parking lots, if you are in a non-preferred lot and get to work late, you may have trouble finding a space.

review_title: Stable, low-pressure, on the way to paying for your kids' college and retirement; hell if you're ambitious and talented
job_title: IT Analyst, Senior in Durham, NC
pros:
benefits, benefits, benefits (very good health and awesome retirement contribution)
low-stress since it's not run like a business
Durham, NC and Triangle are great places to live
cons:
Since it's not run like a business, talented people are not rewarded; lazy, aging employees will get the same rewards as everyone else
Low salaries. Ridiculously low salaries.
Not the most high-caliber employees. The prestige of Duke pertains to their academics, research, and health system. Most staff would fail miserably at a top-notch RTP company.
Little hope for career challenge or advancement

review_title: Flexible stable position, good benefits,limited salary growth,pay below industry standards.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Durham, NC
pros: Very flexible, some remote work allowed if appropriate for position. Company pays retirement contrib even if you don't. Very good job security if your department is an important one. Good training opportunities, very nice people to work with, family friendly.
cons: Been difficult to have salary growth keep up with inflation. Sensitive to market, had a wage freeze a few years back. Raise less than inflation percent, pay below industry average.

pros: Healthcare Benefits and 401K/Retirement Plan as well as tuition benefit program for children of employees going to college.
cons: Locked in compensation with only upward mobility of two service levels at a time and 5,000 per level, regardless if you originally took a job you were overqualified for or have more experience and education than the new job requires, you are locked in at your starting salary rate and service level for the duration of your career at Duke. Very limited professional growth in certain schools and incompetent supervisors that can’t be disciplined or let go.

job_title: Systems Analyst, Senior in Durham, NC
pros: Working for an academic institution can be a remarkably rewarding experience.  The projects, at least outside of the central IT group, are largely people and research driven, and can be worthwhile.
cons: Different areas are radically different.  The central IT group is a wretched place to work, largely due to poor management and an inability to connect to the larger university purpose.  Departmental/school groups are hit and miss.

review_title: Great time as a teacher's assistant
pros: As a student you get the chance to earn an extra bit of money, besides what your parents provide, while at the same time re-learning material from a past class and helping students within your age range.
cons: The work load of grading papers, attending classes without getting credits, and hosting office hours in place of the professor can take a toll on studies and social life, but otherwise it was a great experience.

review_title: Many cultures, and many of those benign
pros: Lovely campus, generally humanitarian employee policies. And how nice to have access to good libraries, music, performances, and people creating new knowledge--even if they have nothing directly to do with your job!
cons: Parking's a bear, and either expensive or a bit of a hike. Faculty are treated better than staff, as you'd expect--12 weeks of parental leave vs 2 weeks, etc.  A university is a pretty risk-averse place, which may bug you if you're creative.

review_title: Easy work study job made largely intolerable by new mgmt
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Durham, NC
pros:
-Nothing too demanding
-Decent starting pay for a work study job
-You set your own hours, though they do ask you to work one night a week and one weekend per month
cons:
-New management forbade doing homework or even using a computer at the service desk. On slow days this means you sit there and stare into space for the 90% of the time that there is nobody in the store. Excruciatingly boring.
-Management is in general pretty disconnected from students, and pretty much all of the lower employees hate their jobs which makes working there somewhat miserable.

job_title: Research Analyst II in Durham, NC
pros: Researchers truly want to solve problems and (most) are willing to work together, as long as the money is there.  The research is cutting-edge and the environment is fast-paced, at least in my department.  Never a dull moment.
cons: No advancement opportunities - once someone is placed in a position, they don't leave (indicative of how much people really like working here?).  Limited development courses for researchers, more is available for admins.  Grants and many are a constant battle.

review_title: Good work-life balance and intellectual community
job_title: Staff, Fuqua School of Business in Durham, NC
pros:
Love the bright and engaged colleagues and students I work with at Fuqua School of Business
Good work-life balance
My work is interesting and intellectually stimulating
Tuition benefit at Duke is a huge perk that I will take advantage of when my kids reach college age
cons:
Salary is on par with other universities, but of course not comparable to private sector
Career path is very unclear
Business schools are run like schools, not businesses -- that is, we teach management best practices in the classroom, but do not operate our own institution with the efficiency, innovation, or leadership of a business

pros: Duke offers terrific job security, intelligent colleagues, wonderful learning opportunities, and a beautiful location.  Employees also have access to good healthcare, great retirement benefits, and good tuition benefits.
cons: Rigid, hierarchical, and old-fashioned structure that is not open to advancement.  Tenured faculty feel less valued than physicians; housekeeping is at the very bottom of the chain.  Nonetheless, there are departments where this standard is challenged and all are valued according to their contributions.

review_title: Great place to work part-time as a student employee while taking classes at Duke University.
job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: The Textbook store offers decent pay for a fairly simple job.  Sometimes business is slow, but doing classwork during downtime is allowed and encouraged.
cons: When I worked there, student employees were required to work at least one Saturday shift per month, which usually was 6-7 hours long, and I was usually the only employee in the textbook store during those hours.  But on the other hand, 1-2 hour shifts a couple times a week make it difficult to really make any money at this job.

review_title: I've worked at Duke for three years, and it has been a very rewarding experience professionally.
pros: Great health benefits (although it is an HMO), wonderful people with whom to work (except for some faculty members), fascinating projects on which to work. Duke is doing some very exciting work in both research and higher education.
cons: Raises/promotions have been very hard to come by. Even though I believe I have excelled and proven my ability to take on more responsibility, it has been difficult to broaden my role or receive an increase in compensation.

pros: As an instructor you generally get to work with students who are interested in the content area.
cons:
*  Ridiculous Classroom budget
*  Bait and Switch contracting tactics.  For distance sites, you must pay for your own travel expenses.
*  Unreasonable expectations placed upon instructors, and many ways for them to dodge paying you after you have completed the assignment.
LONG HOURS of ~60 hours/week (10 hours per day).
*  You make ~$2300 and give ~180 of direct instructional hours, and generally it's mostly lecture because of the classroom budget.  You make ~$12/hour when all is said and done.
*  Poor track record for reimbursements.  Expect to pay out of your pocket upfront for things you need.
*  Condescending attitude from other faculty stemming from a toxic environment created by the home office.

pros: The Duke community is fun. Work can be intense, but it ebbs and flows with the academic calendar. Great benefits.
cons:
Terrible parking situation. This seems like a small issue, but I find it reprehensible to pay $860 to park near my building. The next closest available parking is 1/2 mile away, inconsistently available (sometimes have to park farther away), and bus service is only reasonable when class is in session.
Salary is stagnant and doesn't keep up with inflation or cost of living. It is necessary to move to a new department to advance.

pros: University's Office of Information Technology (OIT) has some very professional, highly skilled technical staff - you need to run to keep up. Competitive but kind, professional environment.
cons:
Don't confuse Duke University IT (OIT) with Duke Health System IT (DHTS).  OIT is well-managed; DHTS is not.  

Folks in OIT are hard-working and fairly efficient.  Management runs a pretty tight ship there.  DHTS on the other hand, characterized by spin, busy-work, waste, old technology.

pros: Family friendly (depends on PI), huge professional biomedical community, collaborative, basically every apparatus you could think of using in your research is present on campus, within 20 miles of NC Research Triangle Park (60.000 people working in biotech) and UNC and NC State, great postdoc association.
cons: Easy to get overlooked since there are so many good people, Durham is nice and family friendly, but it is a small city and there is not a ton of things to do after hours.

review_title: Elite university served mostly by mediocrity
pros: generous retirement benefits, access to Duke health care, scenic environment, university culture, diversity, job stability
cons: extreme tolerance for mediocre talent, very low starting pay for auxiliary functions (the non-academics, non-medical-professionals, non-elite-researchers, etc.), little chance of significant pay increases, bureaucracy

review_title: A good, stable place to work
pros: Great health benefits, good work/life balance, generally respectful environment for staff.  Staff are evaluated and eligible for small raises annually.
cons: Like most universities, the only way to get a raise greater than cost-of-living is to get promoted to management position or get another job within the University.

pros:
**In the academic sector, not the medical**
-Work with great PIs that listen and are genuinely interested in helping you do what you would like to do 
-Great work environment, people are very open-minded and open to dialogue about various subjects. Aside from great PIs and managers, this is one of the reasons I've stayed so long
-Opportunity to work on plenty of projects
-Opportunity to go to conferences to see what other people are working on
-Flexible time
cons:
-Academia pay is low
-Not many opportunities to move up vertically
-Parking is expensive and continues to get expensive every single year despite the fact that Duke says they won't increase (premium lots are incredibly expensive)

pros:
- Great mission that goes beyond building the next generation of thinkers and leaders. So many centers exist doing internationally renowned work. 
- Generous benefits (vacation, sick days, Duke at work challenges from HR)
- Coworkers feel like family
- Many stay with Duke for a lifetime and move around to different jobs - there are alot of opportunities.
cons:
- lower pay because it is a non-profit
- As a monthly employee you get paid once a month which can be tough to budget for
- Some people have been here for TOO long and don't put effort into their jobs but won't get fired.

pros: More collaborative and entrepreneurial than one might anticipate; Breadth of professional development opps; Relatively small size translates into accessibility to faculty, staff, leadership.
cons: Awash in politics, pettiness, and downside of leading university that hires from local network or trailing spouses into leadership roles, for instance. This is nothing new in academe; multi-billion dollar orgs with amateur management in most ranks except those most senior.

review_title: Great place to work ... if you like academic politics
job_title: Seniro IT Analyst in Durham, NC
pros: The benefits are good and, depending on the department you work in, the work can be more stable than the private sector.
cons: Duke is decentralized, so there's no consistency in accountability and management.  Central HR and administrators more or less let different units and departmental heads and managers "do their own thing", so often getting ahead depends more on who you know that what you've accomplished.  Units and departments don't talk to each other and often compete for attention and funding.  It's a rather negative and confrontational atmosphere with no accountability for senior management.

pros: Good support and community that is fairly open to change.  Excellent knowledge sharing between units.  Great benefits beyond compensation. Great place to live.
cons: Parking.  Salaries are low (case in all of higher ed), but better than most institutions.  Top tier management seems a little out of touch with some functional concerns.  However they do a good job of implementing their big picture ideas.

pros: It's a great university with a multitude of opportunities, good compensation, and plenty of opportunities for advancement, professional and otherwise. You learn new things everyday which is something to look forward to. The pay is better than other Durham employers, and the benefits are as well. Yet people will still complain about it. I should not speak for everyone though since I only represent a tiny fraction of the overall employee body.
cons: Sometimes you encounter rude people, but that's what you should expect anywhere. In general the culture is very professional and academic. Typical research university culture.

pros: DCRI has many development opportunities. There are a lot of education perks and therapeutic training available, which is a nice perk if you are a licensed professional.
cons: As a universtiy, the pay is lower than industry. There also seems to be a lot of red-tape once you are in the system, so it becomes very difficult to move up the ladder. Managers seem to be fairly complacent and will not push to get needed promotions through. A lot of talent leaves the company due to this issue.

pros: If you are academic-minded, then Duke is among the best. You will have ample exposure to academics from elsewhere, and receive the best training in the US to conduct cutting-edge research.
cons: If you are looking for career development outside academia, then Duke might not be the best place to start with. Try look for a job in the private sector where you can always learn more and rise faster.

pros: A sense of pride that comes from working for an established and highly respected institution for higher learning.  Sound benefits package with on site training classes for non-faculty administrators to gain the skills they may need to advance within the University system.  Vacation and sick time accrual.  Opportunities for interaction with diverse cultures and perspectives can be rewarding.
cons: Solid administrative management at the higher level within departments is lacking.  Tenured academics, in particular,  do not always possess the kind of leadership skills needed to effectively oversee staff.  Their teaching and research responsibilities can impede the administrative process.

pros: Feedback from a graduate student, instructor and lecturer in the humanities: this is a great place to be a graduate student from a career development perspective. Duke is a wealthy private university, so class sizes are small, typically c. 10-30 students in a humanities class. You get independent teaching experience very quickly: as a teaching assistant in your second and third years, and full responsibility for a small seminar (c. 10-15 students) in your fourth and fifth years. I also had the opportunity to teach two larger (c. 30 students) lecture type classes. The Graduate School also offers a Teaching Certificate, which requires you to take classes that are actually practical - teaching observation, portfolio and website development, etc. The stipend is generous given the relatively cheap living conditions in the area - you can have a normal life and an apartment of your own, or quite luxurious accommodations if you share. So it is possible to graduate with a PhD and no debt whatsoever if you manage your finances well.
cons: Feedback from a graduate student, instructor and lecturer in the humanities: the Graduate School is not very good at communicating with grads on practical matters, such as parking, external funding, and funding for grad student fees and healthcare past your fifth year. You really have to think ahead and ask a lot of questions which should really be in an email newsletter somewhere sent to you regularly. Departments also have individual power over some of the graduation requirements, which may not be written down or set out explicitly and half the time the profs have no clue either. Also, certain Graduate School policies - such as on sexual assault and harassment - are a mess, it's not clear what the process is at graduate level. The Grad Student Govt is now working on this. Summary: there usually is a process, but the School is not very good about its communication, which means that if you're not careful, you might end up fire-fighting various issues later in your grad career. I've done a lot of this research on my own, and was continually surprised at how little other graduate students knew about various things - I can't even count the number of times that someone said, "wow, how do you know that? I didn't..."

review_title: I'm post-doc, so my experiences are dependent on the lab!
pros: As a post doc, Duke has obviously put some time into offering good support infrastructure in terms of the programs that help post-docs maintain training while looking for jobs (DUPA, for example). Benefits are good enough. Obviously a lot of the pros are more associated with the lab you choose than the company itself.
cons: It's private, and that shows in some ways. Parking costs a lot for the area, the benefits are more expensive than I'd like, and it's small enough that seminars coming through are lacking.

review_title: Good reputation, but HR policies don't treat postdocs well
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Durham, NC
pros: Highly respected academic research institution. Great research facilities available (metabolomics, mass spec, RNAseq, Mircroarray, etc). In general, the people at Duke all seem very nice. As with any postdoc position, your mentor has the most control over whether you are happy and satisfied.
cons:
HR policies for postdocs at Duke are some of the worst I've seen. Duke won't pay for a postdoc's health insurance for the first month, so the postdoc must pay the full premium on their own. They only benefit is the fact that you are then covered for an additional month after you end employment. 

Postdocs have to go to the Duke new employee orientation, which is pointless because 99% of the information they go over does not apply to a postdoc. Postdocs aren't "real" employees at Duke, and thus, do not get most of the benefits they offer to employees. Postdocs do not get retirement benefits and cannot take advantage of the dependent care reimbursement account. I'm sure there are a lot of other HR benefits that postdocs are not eligible for as well. 

If you get your own funding to support your research and salary, you are completely cut off from benefits. While you can still buy into the health insurance plan, you have to pay the FULL premium out of your grant, and thus you are paying taxes on that full amount. Additionally, since grant money isn't considered earned income, you can't contribute to any retirement plan on your own, and like I mentioned, Duke doesn't offer retirement to postdocs anyway. Combined with the low pay of a postdoc, it makes for a pretty awful financial situation, especially if one has a family.

As with any postdoc position, there is little room for upward mobility within the same institution.

pros: Good benefits, smart people, nice campus. Durham has a lot to offer for a relatively small city -- night life, restaurants, concerts, entertainment, good nearby parks and recreational opportunities. Duke is a stable employer.
cons: Almost no opportunity for advancement within a department. You have to move out in order to move up. Parking is inconvenient and expensive. Many managers have no managerial training whatsoever. Micromanagement is common. Application of policies and procedures can be inconsistent, with rules arbitrarily enforced on some people and not others. There is very little diversity at the higher levels -- it's almost entirely old, white men. Staff are treated with disdain by some members of the faculty and senior management. Raises are the same for everyone whether your performance is good, bad or mediocre. Raises do not keep pace with inflation. Female employees at all levels are treated like a servant class. Workload can increase dramatically while staffing remains flat. Office spaces are overloaded with too many employees in spaces that are too small. Employees' needs are disregarded.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: This was the most relaxed and friendly workplace I've ever had the pleasure of working in. Things aren't super time sensitive, so people can socialise while they work or take their time to make sure things are done right.
cons: Not super exciting. As a research assistant, sometimes it felt like they were having a hard time finding things for me to do. Be prepared for lab drudgery and of course washing the glassware.

pros: Working with a multitude of people, you spend lots of time with fellow employees and not much with the students. Hours aren't too early.
cons: Hours are long, however. This job usually requires a 1PM-10PM daily shift, including weekends. This isn't so bad for the most part, but it is frustrating to not be able to enjoy free time after about 8PM/9PM sometimes. If you don't get along with some of your coworkers, it's a bit of a problem. You spend almost all of your time with the rest of the administrative staff.

pros: Duke has very good acacemic reputation in the nation. There are plenty of resources available and you will be working with / learning from smart people.
cons: There is a lot of pressure in getting things done. Everyone pushes very hard. You need to really well to survive in the competitive environment. Another disadvantage is that Duke is not close to big cities.

pros: Taught me to work more independently and rely on myself.
cons: Terrible administration. They made life very difficult.  Ranomly will lose your insurance, or not get paid one month, or lose an opportunity because someone failed to compltete a form on time. I wish it was an irregular occurrance, but it's not. It happens to everyone.

review_title: The good ol' boy system, just like most corporate companies.
pros: It is family friendly. But it seems like there is someone taking off every other month for maternity or paternity leave. Generous sick leave, but some people take advantage just like in Corporate.
cons: Working in academia they always expect you to learn something quickly, use it, then present it. They always want you to present on everything.

pros: Good benefits, nice campus, friendly staff members.  My work load is not overwhelming, and I feel as though I have job security.
cons: My department has minimal training and very poor leadership.  There are many inconsistencies across departments on campus.  Parking is expensive.  Salary is not competitive... they assume people want to work at Duke, so they don't have to pay them well.

pros: Wonderful people, very congenial and supportive atmosphere. Understanding if you have a conflict or are busy with other work, respond well to good faith effort.
cons: Holding a position lacking great responsibility I would occasionally be left out of the loop when something was cancelled or rescheduled, leading once or twice to my showing up to work when nothing was going on.

pros: great place to work.  There is some "politics" around but overall its a wonderful place to work and there are a lot of great people.
cons: Not a lot of advancement opportunities.  If you are looking to learn and advance your skills at a healthy place, this is not the place to work.  You do get to choose 1 training class a year, which is nice, but not a lot, if any, on the job training to advance skills.

review_title: Non-PhD research scientist - excellent experience-building and networking; hard for ambitious people to build a career
job_title: Laboratory Research Analyst II in Durham, NC
pros:
Duke is a huge employer (largest in NC) so there are literally thousands of vantage points to review from, but I will give the perspective of a non-PhD research lab tech/analyst at the School of Medicine.  Individual experiences will vary widely by lab and department, but overall Duke is an excellent place to get your foot in the door in world-class research.  Getting into research here is an excellent opportunity for recent college graduates looking for experience before graduate school or medical school, to build experience for industry research positions, and, if you find your niche and are comfortable where you are, Duke could be a great place to spend an entire career.

The biggest pro for me is the immersion in world class research.  You will get to work with some of the brightest and thoughtful people you will ever meet in your career.  The medical school and research campus is massive and it is amazing the sheer amount and quality of research that goes on here.  Access to conferences and other events will give you invaluable knowledge and experience in your field.  If you can get a job here straight from your undergraduate, grab it with both hands, as it is an excellent career first stop for any scientist.

The typical progression for those with a BS is to start at Research Tech II, which pays a competitive entry-level hourly wage.  With a masters, or after two years at the tech level, you are eligible for the salaried Lab Research Analyst I position, which brings a few perks, which I will mention below.  The hours are flexible and you get two weeks vacation to start (3 once salary), plus 12 holidays (5 floating), and sick leave.  The health insurance options are good, but you have to use Duke doctors if you want one of the cheaper options.  Hourly positions are under a pension plan paid by Duke, but once salary, Duke contributes at least 9% to your 403b automatically.  Other great benefits include tuition reimbursement for your children (Duke will pay a certain percentage each year for your child's college tuition (Duke or not) above a certain amount), among others you can check out at hr.duke.edu.

If you get into a growing/well-funded institute or lab and perform well you can jump job levels quickly, which is really the only way to make more money as raises were 2% each year I didn't receive a promotion.  The structure is set up so that one can jump up a few positions quickly but after ~7-10 years/3 level increases (to Lab Research Analyst, Senior) there's really only one more step up, so long term growth stagnates. 

As with any major university, the perks of being associated are innumerable: farmer's market, gyms, intramurals, employee appreciation football game, museum discounts, access to all that the university has to offer.  You are definitely at the cultural heart of the city.

Job security is also a plus, as even if funding runs out in your lab, Duke will find a place for you elsewhere.  People have worked here for 40+ years, having to jump labs and departments along the way.  Additionally, Duke seems open to people changing career paths and moving from lab positions into, for example, clinical or administrative positions within the organization.  They definitely seem to want to keep good people and try to do what it will take to keep them.
cons:
The only two major cons that I can list from my whole experience, and my reasons for leaving, were pay and room for growth.  As an academic institute, the salaries are not comparable to industry money.  While not meager by any stretch, one does begin to feel the pinch of paltry 2% yearly raises with a growing family.  Glassdoor is an excellent reference to get an idea of what to expect, but as I said, promotions are the only way to get ahead financially.  While the entry-level pay is comparable to what you might get from industry, the salary growth with experience is much more modest than what one could expect with a company.

The other major con is room for growth, at least for my ambitions.  As a non-PhD scientist you are always going to be a tier below anyone with a PhD/MD, so upper level positions will be hard to come by.  Additionally, those non-PhD/MDs in management positions tend to stay there so there are very few opportunities to get to the top.  Switching to a non-laboratory role within Duke is an option, but was not appealing to me.  Basically, one hits their pay-band ceiling at around 5-10 years, with maybe one more jump before retirement.

Minor cons include parking (free=nonexistent)  either pay $80 per month to park in a deck (good luck finding one without a waitlist) or pay less to park and ride the bus.  Or bike if you can.  Also, as with most college campuses in urban environments, you wouldn’t want to be out alone after hours.  However, Durham gets a bad rap and around the main campus is not as bad as some might let on.

pros: Extremely stimulating place to be. Full of opportunities and professional growth. Wonderful location. Relaxed paced but with all the opportunities of a big city.
cons: Very political in the Humanities, extremely ideological, which makes sometimes difficult to make research, because everybody is following a political agenda instead a knowledge quest.

pros: Good name on the resume; relatively casual dress; beautiful campus; mostly good funding for projects and if you're lucky you'll work with smart people.
cons:
Culture (and your experience in general) is entirely dependent on your immediate team/center. Because the organization is so vast, there is little practical emphasis on culture/values in the aggregate, as you would see in the private sector. The result in my experience was a poorly managed, very isolating and unproductive environment run by toxic leaders. They have already spent a significant percentage of allotted time & money for their grant-funded project, and have not produced any research at all. I could not wait to get out of there, but it was clearly not Duke's fault. Some professors/researchers just are terrible managers who should NOT be supervising others, and are not at all incentivized to improve in that area.

While my brain recognizes that this extremely negative microcosm was not representative of Duke as a whole, I do think it says something about the structure/norms of academia. That was enough to give me pause about pursuing an academic career. I left to work at a startup, which has the exact opposite approach. My ratings below are STRICTLY about the center at which I worked; I have no doubt that others have had stellar experiences in other areas of the university. 

If they are concerned, I would advise future applicants to ask questions about culture and leadership to see how thoughtful their hiring managers are about those topics. Do not assume that the university name guarantees intellectual rigor, honesty, or even competence. On the other hand, you can survive anything if you simply want to stay for a year before grad school.

review_title: PhD student in Biological Sciences at Duke University
pros: Great work-life balance, friendly colleagues, supportive training environment, stipend is high compared to PhD programs at other private or public universities. Living expenses are generally low in Durham so you can save money if you want to.
cons: The general vibe is more laid-back and more focused on application than pure academic research. If you are shooting for academia jobs or enjoy a more intense environment, Duke might not be your best match.

review_title: PhD student in Biological Sciences at Duke University
pros: Great work-life balance, friendly colleagues, supportive training environment, stipend is high compared to PhD programs at other private or public universities. Living expenses are generally low in Durham so you can save money if you want to.
cons: The general vibe is more laid-back and more focused on application than pure academic research. If you are shooting for academia jobs or enjoy a more intense environment, Duke might not be your best match.

review_title: At first it was cool, but now not so much.
pros:
1. Child Tuition Assistance (for those who work in the University, not the Medical Center).
2. Excellent retirement plan.
3. Stability - Duke isn't going anywhere anytime soon.
cons:
1. Salaries are lower than market.
2. Outside of the Child Tuition Assistance and retirement match, the benefits are the same as any other company.
3. Moving from University to Medical will eliminate Child Tuition Assistance.
4. Horrible managers are allowed to wreck havoc and get rid of competent, hard workers.
5. It's hard to move around once you reach a certain level. Many employees are as high as they can go, but lack the experience to move to another department. There is no training that will bridge the gap.
6. Minorities occupy the low-level jobs, but aren't seen in very many management positions.
7. There is no succession plan for employees.
8. Out of touch with the current workforce.

job_title: Technical Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Duke is a great place to work as a student. There are numerous valuable employment opportunities in campus, and you get to learn a lot.
cons: The only issue I can think of is that some jobs require you to have work study, but even if you don't there are plenty of jobs that you can get as a student.

review_title: Good people, good education, some silly institutional rules
pros: Lots of good people (fellow students, professors, staff, etc.). The education is rigorous, exactly what you would want from a high-class graduate degree.
cons: There are some silly institutional rules that stifle student flexibility in work, both during the summer and during the academic year. This is unfortunate, because learning by doing as a research or teaching assistant is one of the most effective ways to spend your time as a a graduate student.

review_title: The promotion of individuals solely on the basis of the fact that they possess a PhD is a form of inbreeding.
job_title: Financial Analyst III in Durham, NC
pros:
*Educational Benefit, both for employees and children of employees is great, but you sacrifice annual bonuses for this benefit
*Retirement Plan is one of the better benefits
*Health Insurance Benefit Package is good
cons:
**Lack of advancement opportunities
**Low salary levels compared to comparable corporate entities
**No annual bonus
**Having to pay for the right to park your car

pros:
- highly collaborative environment, people are friendly
 - good weather
 - intelligent professors & coworkers
 - lots of resources (shared instrumentation facilities)
 - pretty campus for work breaks
 - inexpensive gym access (nice gym)
 - good healthcare
cons:
- parking sucks
 - parking *really* sucks
 - campus food is OK, not great.  Durham has much better offerings.
 - HR & departmental administrative staff could run a little more efficiently, but very nice people.  It just takes a while to get things done.
 - Did I mention the parking yet?

review_title: Great place to do a PhD
pros: Good support for PhD students, lots of potential well-funded advisers to choose from in the sciences, and cheap cost of living. Durham/Raleigh/Chapel Hill area is not too populated, which I think is great, and there's plenty going on if you look for it.
cons: Has a Divinity school, which isn't too far from the science department. Durham isn't the safest place. Admins may cater a little too much to undergrads, but hey, they are paying big bucks for an education they could have had online anyway.

review_title: Chemistry department is a good place to do a PhD
pros: The people in the lab I work in maintain a good work-life balance. The department is actively working to improve diversity and inclusiveness.
cons: Some other students have difficulty with work-life balance or with other students in the program, and resources to address these problems are not always readily available. Graduate student pay should be increased to allow us to afford a good standard of living. It is difficult to make ends meet on our stipends, especially for people without a live-in partner.

review_title: Stuck in tradition, Aspirations to change
pros: Benefits if you work there long enough to retire.  Great opportunities for special events and activities.  The ability to transfer to other job fields and school areas while remaining a Duke employee.  Interaction with some special faculty and students.
cons: Resistance to change and new ideas.  Managers who have no experience with supervising personnel.  Inaction when personnel issues are brought up, unless a potential law suit is involved.

review_title: Large, Complicated but Well Run organization
pros:
Great benefits
Company is doing good things
Smart people
Entrepreneurial
cons:
Lots of red tape, complicated
Low pay compared to other universities in the area and nationally
Department rules can deviate from university standards

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Great access to world class research. Faculty and staff are engaged in the scientific progress of the students. If you are looking for a place to get the best scientific training this is place to be. Lots of resources, to do anything you want.
cons:
Competitive if you dont come from an Ivy League background. 
Little support if you want to pursue industry.
Quality of your experience depends on your adviser 100%

review_title: Great place for a work-study at Duke
pros: Employees are chill. Make friends with peers. Flexibility in scheduling. Its' in Perkins. Work hours can be 8-20hrs/week and you can distribute them however you want pretty much, based on your class schedule.
cons: Work is dull. You end up having to fix people's computers off-hours because you're "the kid who works for OIT." If you're not a big fan of reddit or other internet forums, you might be excluded from a lot of conversations, because everyone else is big into that.

job_title: Associate In Research in Durham, NC
