pros: Great to be around such innovation.  Great medical insurance.  If you happen to work in a research group with a reasonable advisor, it can be a great experience.
cons: Duke is very focused on keeping up with other universities, so their faculty are worked hard and spread thin.  This often means that staff are not treated with as much respect and patience as one deserves.  If one has an ally in your direct P.I., then this problem is minimized.

review_title: Positive experience with the ability for professional development and growth.
pros: I love working at Duke because the people are so caring and easy to get along with. I also have had the opportunity to travel to conferences and become certified in areas pertinent to my job.
cons: I love the department I work in but I have heard that other departments are more traditional. Also, as a University, it takes longer for new technologies to kick in.

review_title: Great experience, but so much depends on your manager
pros: Duke is nice to work for if you are in a well-funded area. There are opportunities for professional growth and trying new things. The people are respectful and welcoming. West Campus is lovely to work on especially.
cons: The bureaucracy of a big organization is frustrating. From what I've learned from others who work there, so much of your experience depends on the people you report to. Some faculty are wonderful to work for, and some are terrible.

pros: Extremely generous time off.  Excellent benefits.  Really good salaries.
cons: Senior leadership out of touch with employees and the gap between 'managers' and 'staff' continues to grow.  Lots of lip service from senior leadership but minimal improvement.  FAVORITISM RUNS RAMPANT!!!  Very little growth opportunity for the vast majority of employees.  Duke has scaled way back on the little things that help make employees happy like holiday parties and service recognition gifts.

pros: PhD stipend is competitive among equivalent programs in other universities. Living expenses in Durham are relatively low compared to other cities in the US. In general, there can be a good work-life balance.
cons: Some labs may have toxic culture, make sure you talk to the current PhD students in the lab before you commit to a PI as your PhD advisor.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New Durham, NH
pros: Benefit/ healthcare, gym benefit, some discounts, use of library
cons: Low salary, poorly trained managerial staff no consistency across the university each department is its own little fiefdom where racism and races ideas abound. They allow someone who hit the black worker in a car to still continue to work there. They don't hold themselves accountable to stopping out bias behavior.

review_title: Learned a lot as an entry level position but job becomes stagnant after 1-1.5 years service.
pros: Looks good on a resume.
cons: They try to sell you on the University’s prestige, but that doesn’t pay the bills. Difficult to get a raise or promotion, at least in Cell Bio department. Low-balled on pay, have to settle for pay between the minimum and 25th percentile based on Duke’s pay range tables per position title.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Duke has a really great infrastructure in place. Between the research facilities and the hospital you can almost always find someone willing to share insight.
cons: Your individual experience naturally depends on the department and the group for which you work. Some facilities are better equipped and better maintained than others, but overall it was above average.

review_title: Duke TiP Summer Studies Academic Program Assistant
job_title: Academic Program Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Good environment, you're not dealing directly with students like if you were a TA, and it's pretty up to you how much you want to get involved with the residential program. It's a nice alternative to being in an office all the time if you're looking for a summer job
cons: You have to live in Duke's old first-year dorms, not ideal accommodations. You're working at a summer camp when it gets down to it, so if that's not your thing it might not be for you

pros: Management was very understanding of personal life interfering with work, and they allowed me to address my own issues before expecting me to address my work tasks.
cons: Although they were understanding in certain times of need, there was difficulty in managing all of the required work within the time frame they specified.

review_title: Not recommended-former DUSON Program Coordinator Employee
pros: Good work flexibility for salary employees.
cons:
Supervisors/directors  are very incompetent who are overseeing grant funded projects and very lazy. 

Those in grant funded positions risk being eliminated any time without factual or reasonable cause just as temp position workers.

Supervisors need leadership training and are known to treat their employees poorly once they come onboard work arrangements agreed at hire are subject to change;  get agreements in writing. DUSON is Not a place to look to for a career.

pros: Obviously there are perks in being a grad student:  a PhD (eventually), flexible schedule, the opportunity to work with very smart people and advance your career
cons: Durham isn't the greatest city ever (but not terrible).  5 years at a grad student pay rate is miserable.  The low pay is really the only major negative.

review_title: Overall, the Duke work culture is very similar to the Duke University culture - passive aggressive.
pros: There are the obvious benefits of working for Duke basketball program - seamless entry to all Duke basketball games. I also received lots of free Duke gear.
cons: The work culture is passive aggressive.  If there are inter-office issues, there aren't many avenues through which people can talk it out.

review_title: Duke is a great place to work!
pros: Duke has great people, good benefits, good professional growth opportunities, and a great work/life balance.  Overall, it's a great place to work.
cons: Compensation is the main thing that comes to mind, but I'm sure that it has a lot to do with it being a university, however, it would seem that there would be more wiggle room since it's a private university.

pros:
- Very friendly and welcoming community. Especially within the departments, there is an effort to be inclusive and supportive of all staff. 
- Outstanding benefits for individuals of all ages and families.
- Freedom to take on new responsibilities and adapt your role to your strengths and interests.
- Flexible work hours and e-commuting policy
- Access to Duke facilities (i.e. gym) and university events (athletics, etc.)
cons:
- Mixed experiences in faculty-staff dealings.
- Pay is not that competitive, and no bonuses are offered. 
- Hours are generally regular

job_title: Instructor, Clinical Medicine in Durham, NC
pros: Collaborative research environment. Emphasis on investment in core facilities.
cons: Corrupt and regressive administration.  Programs and leadership pay lip service to improvement in areas of diversity, salary, experience, but do not do the work or invest the resources to achieve this improvement.  Very poor place to work as a woman.  Challenges faced by junior women are not addressed and statement is made that "senior leadership is women" and thus there can not be an issue with things like research materials or data being stolen by male senior staff (with directly discriminatory statements made contemporaneously).

pros: opportunities to learn, surrounded by extremely motivated and smart people, working at a world-class university, better able to weather financial downturns than the rest of higher education
cons: low salaries for staff comparatively, hard to move up career-wise, people work here for a long time and some don't have any interest to learn new things or do things differently

review_title: Good work environment, an impression of low promotion opportunities
pros: Duke tries to be pro-active with helping employees with things like commute cost, health insurance, etc. Graduate students have official advocates on staff. Fairly liberal compensation policies, and a stable workplace feel. Accommodations for kids, etc. Pets are allowed as long as one is responsible for them.
cons: The impression among staff is that pay and promotions are somewhat stagnant. Hard negotiators and up-and-comers would be loathe to work here unless they are in upper management. Parking is always an issue.

pros: If you enjoy research in an academic hospital, Duke is one of the few places in the world that will provide you with the ideal environment for pursuing your goals.
cons: The main downside for me is the location. I am allergic to pollen and North Carolina happens to be one of the worst places for that.

review_title: Great place to work and research
pros: You have the chance to work along steamed scientist. Provides a balanced work - life combination especially if you are in research. Health insurance is also good.
cons: High stress if you are in training in clinical fields. Some research labs look old and not equipped with top notch technology, although it is improving pretty quickly.

pros: Duke creates an environment where you can collaborate across multiple disciplines and explore research interests that are outside of your immediate fied of expertise.
cons: The compensation was not the best given the responsibilities and expectations but this varied from lab to lab. The benefits were okay but not great.

pros: Duke has pretty good medical benefits and if you are ever laid off they will help you find another position within the Duke system but it kind of depends on your department.  Duke also promotes having a work/home life balance and they try hard to be flexible but again depends mainly on your department and Supervisor.
cons: Hard to move up to higher positions with higher compensation and high-cost of parking is also a downer.

review_title: Your advancement in terms of gaining knowledge is highly dependent upon your advisor
pros:
1) Great research in the field of nanotechnolgy
2) Helpful colleagues/fellow graduate students
3) One can learn through various seminars offered and through courses from any department at duke
cons:
1) Professional development is not the greatest
2) No other cons come to mind
3) No other cons come to mind

pros: Large size- able to move around in company in different positions to further career, great location, very good benefits offered to employees including wellness initiatives, opportunity to take on extra projects, opportunity for continuing education, friendly coworkers, great overall environment
cons: Because it is so large, it was sometimes difficult to navigate the campus area and find the right building for meetings. It would have been nice to not have to pay for parking, but it was not very expensive.

review_title: Outstanding benefits with lots of politics
pros: Lots of resources available.  Don't have to work too hard if you don't want to. Benefits are absolutely fantastic, particularly the retirement plans and if you have kids, the educational benefit.
cons: If you do want to work hard, opportunities for advancement are not easy to come by.  There's definitely an academic old boy's network in place.  Depending on the department, some interesting work is happening, but mostly it's not too challenging for the typical administrative staff member.

review_title: A great place to spend a year or two gaining experience and trying out different things.
pros: Great work-life balance and a ton of flexibility in terms of scheduling. There are a lot of networking opportunities and plenty of interesting people to meet. Since it's a university you also get the added benefit of using all the facilities and resources.
cons: The pay is pretty low (though not terribly low), and there's essentially no room for advancement. This isn't true of all positions, just this one.

pros:
Laid back and relaxed
Room to gain new skills and learn.
The total compensation package is well above the average. ie vacation time, retirement plan, flex time, ect...
cons: I haven't found any yet, although I have been told that moving up / raises are not as easy at other places.

pros: Team Oriented Culture which leads to developing quality students and employees.  Has a great brand name and is respected in the professional world.
cons: There is at times a disconnect between the University and its students.  This is possibly do to the diversity of the student body and the University's interest in satisfying as many people as possible.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Durham, NC
pros: Benefits, friendly work environment, job duties clearly defined. Each department or division  operates differently!!!!! It really hard to compare.
cons: You have to know someone to get hired on the University side, little room for growth, no incentive for excelling - everyone gets the same 3% raise. When the grant is over - you are on your own. HR does not help keep great employees.

review_title: Great professional development, wonderful colleagues, beautiful work campus.
pros: Professional development, collaborative culture, family friendly polices.  Wonderful being around motivated and engaged students.  Love having the opportunity to attend talks from subject matter experts around  the world.  I appreciate how the University supports the Durham community.
cons: Some colleagues are lower performers and still are rewarded with keeping their jobs.  Some top performers are overlooked and brown nosers are rewarded.

pros: Excellent people, stimulating environment, unparalleled basketball and spirit. As a student assistant, supervisors were exceptionally understanding of student schedule demands
cons: Duke is academically rigorous and can be difficult at times. Student assistant positions can offer minimal growth opportunities, more just placeholders to gain a bit of experience and earn that work study.

pros: First of all, the weather is nice. Duke university provides convenient access to nearly every resources. It locates near research triangle park,  it is easy to communicate and collabporate with other researches.
cons: If you like living in a  city, Duke University probabily is not your best choice. Besides that, I cant think of anything else.

review_title: Faculty are frequently horrible bosses, but the University itself is a nice place to work
pros:
Kind employees
High intellectual stimulation available (classes, research fields)
Beautiful campus
Higher management is alright, where not faculty
Great benefits, including tuition assistance for self and family
cons:
Faculty are frequently unpleasant to work for - people hired for intelligence and that they get things done, not hired for skill in teaching, mentoring, or administration.
Lack of focus in many departments
Lack of communication between departments

review_title: An enjoyable experience but not one I am looking to repeat.
pros: It was nice to have the opportunity to see another college campus. And it is great that they provide dinning and lodging for all of their employees. I especially enjoyed most of my colleagues and fellow instructional staff.
cons: My main complaint is that as a teaching assistant your duties are completely determined by your instructor and oftentimes you may not be given the opportunity to exercise all of your skills and knowledge.

job_title: Public Relations Specialist in Durham, NC
pros: Very flexible business attire, notable brand, opportunities to transfer jobs across multiple departments. Professional development is really important. You can take a lot of classes offered by the university. The fitness facilities are nice to work in. The athletic teams are very successful. You can get tickets occasionally to games.
cons: Moves slow on decision making, outdated systems, some old ways of thinking. The vacation time off isn't a lot. The pay isn't a lot in comparison to other higher education.

review_title: It's a wonderful place to work
pros: Respected institution, great environment, lots of collaboration and funding. Having a hospital as part of the campus is really useful for collaborations and research.
cons: Parking isn't great, health benefits could be better, they have no idea how to deal with ice and snow in the winter, and there is sometimes crime near campus

pros: Great learning opportunities and colleagues. Benefits are great but do cost a bit if covering a family. Child tuition credits for undergrad education are worth working at duke for, if you have children that age.
cons: Salary compression issues. As you stay longer your benefits get even more impressive but your pay is locked at 10% increases if you move up levels. People coming in new end up making much more than you even though you have seniority.

pros: Duke has a "cradle to grave" approach to employees.  With benefits that include family health, dental, insurance, employee appreciation days/picnics, and even a generous "widows/orphans" type plan, Duke attempts to treat employees as family and provide the necessary support structure to keep its staff happy.
cons: The only down side I ever noticed was a lower pay scale than some other academic institutions and certainly a much lower pay scale than that in private industry.

review_title: Progressive benefits for adjunct teachers, relatively speaking
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Durham, NC
pros: I had a great experience teaching at Duke. Great students and colleagues. Their rate for adjunct teachers is almost twice what other area universities pay and you are eligible for benefits, which makes a huge difference when you are struggling with an adjunct salary.
cons: Not much contact or networking during the semester.

pros: The management team was great at my site, and I had a terrific working relationship with my immediate boss. It is a fairly easy summer job.
cons: There's not a lot of opportunity for professional growth unless you are interested in teaching. Also, the camp sessions are fairly short, so it's difficult to grow your role and implement new practices.

pros: The location where Duke University is located is pretty, which is in the research triangle park (RTP) area. I think that is helpful for staffs who want to seek for other employment opportunities.
cons: Staffs at Duke have to buy pass/permit to the recreation building, but personally, I feel that Duke should provide staffs with complimentary access to recreation buildings to encourage staffs take exercise after work.  This is the only downside I fell as of now.

review_title: Chill Place to Work & Great Boss!
pros: My boss, Yunyi Wang, is the nicest person. She's patient as you learn the job while also keeping you accountable. You can do homework and read while you work the desk routing books and other things in. You can also listen to music while shelving books. It's awesome and I really enjoyed it!
cons: It can be quiet and boring at times. Time sometimes seems to drag on when you're sitting at the desk.

review_title: Excellent first job out of school
pros: Great learning environment for getting accustomed to office work, flexible hours, good pay and great health insurance, perks of working at a college campus like library access and free movies.
cons: Duke is weirdly inflexible about certain things, like making you pay for parking and use vacation hours if the office closes due to weather.

review_title: Skilled but not necessarily fair play
pros: Well funded. Remarkable access to resources. Peer recognition. Highly specialized opportunities. Limited regulatory/oversight constraints. Great seminars and professional events. Low cost of living.
cons: Limited breadth of specialization. Limited representation/involvement of underserved groups and demographics. Strong emphasis on economic gain/interests for an academic institution. Locally concentrated power structures. Minimally regulated management practices

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Excellent compensation for students, particularly with the Durham cost of living.  Students can also enroll in health insurance, which is very nice given Duke's powerhouse hospital.
cons: There is incredible variability in the position depending on the principal investigator (PI). Some demand unreasonable dedication from their students.

pros: You get food and living stipend, but that doesn't matter when your living has roaches and no A/C.
cons: Not vetting the Universities that you partner with, things that were done on site that were not in the contract. Within your stipend and the overtime hours that you WILL (not might, but WILL) put in, you will be making less than minimum wage.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
job_title: Assistant Professor of Research in Durham, NC
pros:
Major focus on biomedical research and bridging it into the clinic
Good pay and benefits
Lots of research funding opportunities
Very collegial, many interdisciplinary work groups
Nice location (NC), mild winters, lovely campus
Local Southern hospitality
cons: You're on your own.  This may be the same anywhere, but I have found it hard (from the administrative side) to get help in the lab.

pros: Top notch talent among coworkers. Fair (very fair) compensation. Snazzy offices and computers, as well as a cluster to use for computing.
cons: None to speak of. They might give away your office, I guess? But then you'll get a new one that's comparable in quality.

pros: Top notch talent among coworkers. Fair (very fair) compensation. Snazzy offices and computers, as well as a cluster to use for computing.
cons: None to speak of. They might give away your office, I guess? But then you'll get a new one that's comparable in quality.

pros: good benefits,  beautiful campus, friendly coworkers, reputable, research seems to be easily fundable due to reputation of the university
cons: horrible parking available, limited room for advancement, unfair distribution of work among coworkers, unaccomplishable standards set for employees, high turn over

pros: The networking, the seemingly unlimited resources to tap into in order to conduct research - Vicki Christian, Ellen DeGaffenreid are great.
cons: The Margolis Center is a hastily established center with no SOP for feedback and evaluations. Even after a year of working a culture hasn't been established between its offices.

review_title: Working at Duke's Private Diagnostic Clinic is really great!
pros: Great work culture, good team communication, feeling highly valued and appreciated, somewhat flexible office hours, feels like there are lots of opportunities to grow, I really feel like management on many levels is striving towards excellence
cons: Communal work spaces are great, but lighting is back in individual offices, building tends to be very cold

review_title: Very good overall experience working for Duke University
pros: There are many benefits to working here, great overall experience. My supervisor was very easy to communicate with and always responded promptly to emails. I felt little pressure from my supervisor, and all my tasks were clearly laid out with no room for misinterpretation.
cons: There are no cons that I can think of, as I stated it was an overall very pleasant experience to work for the business school.

pros: The pros of working in the athletic department are free attendance to men's basketball games.
cons: The cons of this work are everything else. You will be worked into the ground, paid next to nothing (they even have interns who work 80 hour weeks doing the same job as full time staff). Your managers will be bitter because pay raises and promotions are few and far between and rarely does the most capable person earn the career advancement they deserve.

pros: A friendly environment of southern hospitality and gentlemannerism, great local benefits for employees since Duke University is the largest employer in Durham
cons: A leading research institution even though the city itself does not have much to offer. Compensation may not always match the work expected

review_title: Might not get it perfect but this institution really does try to look at for its people.
pros: Productive, competitive environment with the brightest minds; manages to foster one of the most collaborative environments I've worked in.  People are very supportive and for how great of an academic/research institution it is, they are not elitist or snooty in the least bit.
cons: Aside from the typical bureaucratic hurdles of any large institution, nothing else too glaring.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros:
The location is good.
The cost of living in Durham NC is low.
There are lots of industries represented in the area making it easy for spousal job placement.
cons:
It's a university so job satisfaction can be highly variable.
Parking can be a pain but isn't as bad as most universities.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Durham, NC
pros: Prestige, world renowned research, great patients, the newer parts of the medical campus are beautiful, excellent retirement account employer contribution for salaried employees
cons: I worked in two different departments at Duke and never had a decent mid-level manager. They all seem to come from decent workers who never learned what management means.

pros: Great coworkers, dedicated staff, surrounded by like-minded individuals, located in a wonderful town.
cons: I don't think there were really any cons. If you take into account the fact that you're working with children, you know what you're getting yourself into from the beginning. Kids will be kids, and that means they'll do some inexplicable things.

pros: great funding opportunities, lots of support for research and travel to conferences (although this may vary from lab to lab), very good statistics classes, strong reputation that allows you to have a lot of opportunities after graduation
cons: feeling of a somewhat disconnected community, some professors who aren't very interested in teaching, some buildings are old and very outdated

review_title: Great work opportunity for current students
pros: Flexible schedule, helpful staff, and a lot of resources to work with. Great work environment. Opportunities to work in conjunction with other employees or individually, depending on preference. Another plus was the amazing networking opportunities.
cons: Not much room for advancement as a student employee. Sometimes there was not much work to do, so it helps to be a self-starter who can suggest projects and find ways to keep busy.

pros: Lack of management makes the job incredibly easy. Lack of customers on East Campus allows you to consistently do homework and read while on the job.
cons: Work gets quite tedious and not challenging at all. Difficult to get motivated and sometimes no reason to even show up for work.

pros: Great benefits for full time employees.  Pleasant atmosphere and work conditions.  Friendly people.  excellent opportunity for work life balance.  competitive salaries.
cons: Awful communication skills (i.e. returning emails, phone calls, etc.)  Neglect in showing advancement opportunities for current employees branching out to other facets of the university.  PARKING.

pros: There are excellent research opportunities and first class medical center with state of the art equipment and facilities for your use
cons: Parking is difficult, permits are expensive, lots are often distant from your office, proximate lots require going on a waitlist for several years

review_title: A great place to work and study
pros:
Full of lots of opportunities to access to different culture and industries.
Daily interacted with smart people and built network with colleagues and alumni.
Beautiful campus with nice weather. 
Also it provides "saferide van" between campus and places near campus after hours.
cons:
Duke University stays at Durham where is not so safe for downtown area.
But if you can take "saferide van" between campus and places near campus after hours.

review_title: Micromanaging and Controlling Supervisors supported by management
job_title: Clinic Service Coordinator in Durham, NC
pros: A little better than the lowest salaries in the nation, but well below median income.
cons: Lack of advancement, inequality in allowing benefits, micromanagement, bullying by supervisors with full support of management. Employee grievance system is supportive of management not employees as was intended. Full retirement not until 65 no matter how many years employed by company.

pros: Great benefits, family friendly, flexible hours, telecommuting possible, decent work culture, nice place to live, tuition reimbursement available, childcare onsite, supportive co-workers, decent vacation, paid maternity leave
cons: Low salary, little job growth, can be slow to implement new ideas, can be resistant to change, heavy meeting culture, HR policies make it difficult to get ahead due to tight restrictions on pay scales and raises when you do finally earn a promotion

pros: Easy to reach out to a professor and ask whether he/she needs a research assistant - most professors are currently conducting research. Great opportunity to work with experienced, well-respected professors. Good first job to put on your resume.
cons: Whether the work is interesting depends on the needs of the professor - at times, work may be data entry. Salary depends on whether the professor has grant money for research.

job_title: Graduate Student, Political Science in Durham, NC
pros: This place has an intensive methodological training and strong academic reputation. You will likely have a good shot at a Poli sci job coming from the Duke University department of political science. I think I have said enough.
cons: The focus tends to be very narrow in terms of research focus, emphasizing primarily methods and stats and formal models. There is a strong sense of dissonance between faculty and graduate students, and within the faculty themselves.

pros: Good work-life balance and friendly coworkers. Flexibility in work schedule as long as the job gets done. I would recommend this employer and there are many positions that are needed.
cons: Salary a bit low, but overall the benefits fills that lack of base pay. There are no other cons except that research funding is getting tougher every year and that adds instability to the job.

pros: Academic culture, employee benefits, retirement contributions, continuing education
cons: Parking is a challenge for some departments.  Just getting from your car to work could count as a workout.  Also, there's no shortage of people that want to work there, so they are able to low-ball folks on salary.  Good for University finances, bad for folks that are trying to advance in their careers financially.

pros: Psychic benefits of doing interesting and valuable work.  Benefits package is good for the area, and includes the infamous"golden handcuffs," the child college tuition benefit.
cons: Decentralized to the point of being disorganized.  Accordingly always a risk that a unit head is a faculty member promoted without managerial aptitude or training.

review_title: Great if you're a researcher/professor; very different as a staff person!
pros: Good benefits and health care
cons: Salary was very bad when I started and only became reasonable just before I left. The politics became awful. Worked insane number of hours.

job_title: Residential Counselor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Provided with free housing and meals, although the quality depends on campus. The atmosphere was also a major plus for me, although that again depends on where you end up.
cons: For the amount of hours worked, the pay is pretty low ($1000 a term after taxes). Also, you never know who else you will be working with until you arrive, so getting along with co-workers is luck of the draw.

job_title: Data Entry Specialist in Durham, NC
pros: I came here for the chance to offer my daughter a better way of life, and to give her the best access to the college benefit that Duke offered
cons: Pay does not keep up with the national rate, and the chance to advance in this area is only given to a chosen few.

review_title: A stable job, but stuck in old ways
job_title: Research Technician II in Durham, NC
pros: Duke offers good basic benefits, a stable job at a good research facility, and some employee appreciation.
cons: I have heard and have now experienced that within many departments at Duke, there is little room for change. Many people are stuck in their ways and there is very poor communication in the department I worked in. Also, parking is very inconvenient.

job_title: Research Technician II in Durham, NC
pros: Allowed to work independently, management receptive to time off and helping expand my role in lab.  Low pressure job and diverse work force both in gender and race.
cons: No raises for second year but university has elected to give all employees a $1,000 bonus which would be the equivalent of a raise for me but for higher earners its not close to a 2-5% raise.

review_title: Fun office environment filled with jokes and support
pros: Office is filled with great people -- everyone is so much fun. Despite doing administrative tasks, there are plenty of jokes from faculty and staff, and it's a very supportive environment where everyone takes an interest in what you're doing. Lots of opportunity for promotion, and there is always free food and drink!
cons: Sometimes can get a little tedious with the administrative work.

pros:
-Rewarding experiences 
-Decent pay (for a summer job)
-Free housing and food
-A lot of creative freedom in lesson planning 
-Great, likeminded colleagues (generally, young professionals and academics)
cons:
-Tiring work, long hours
-Not a lot of authority to deal kids who are disruptive to the learning environment 
-Very inflexible schedule. Cannot get sick or miss class.

pros: Broad autonomy to create and deliver value to students seeking career insight, job search strategies, tools and skills. Smart colleagues, smart students, strong brand.
cons: while there are many resources to learn, the university culture is not oriented toward professional advancement for staff, you have to know why you want to work here and expect to motivate and develop yourself and your own opportunities.

pros:
Surrounded by brilliant Duke professors, post-docs, and grad students.
Lots of ownership over a project I helped design.
Lots of exposure to many different fields of research in my department.
cons: Living in Durham on this pay can be challenging, especially trying to live near campus.

pros: very dynamic environment in academia , lots of opportunities to collaborate with professors in other departments and programs, spaces for growth
cons: Durham is a relatively small city. and the neighborhood is not safe at all. missing the college town style like what is in Chapel Hill

pros: Duke is a solid place to do a postdoc, especially if you're working for a more well known principal investigator.
cons: Duke doesn't have the prestige of Harvard, Stanford, and other comparable schools, so this may be a downside for moving into other jobs.

review_title: Very organized, friendly people, great atmosphere.
job_title: Pratt Tour Guide in Durham, NC
pros: There's a great working environment, and everyone is very supportive and friendly. As an employee, I feel adequately prepared to do my job to the best of my abilities, and the requirements for my job are very clearly laid out.
cons: As with any big company employer, you can get "lost in the shuffle" at times.

review_title: Fulfilling, fast-paced, meaningful experience dedicated to finding a vaccine for HIV.
pros: DHVI fosters independent growth of knowledge and skill sets. They encourage good communication skills and collaboration within departments to make sure that all research is cutting edge. Everyone had the utmost respect for each other and it felt like a family.
cons: There were long hours and it could be stressful at times due to the nature of the work.

pros: fun staff, love working with the whole healthcare team and that it is a teaching hospital. lots of research and collaboration. nurse residency program is great.
cons: needs updating in main duke north building, pay is mediocre. always understaffed, only wants to hire new grads in certain areas.

pros: Nothing bad to say- Great university and staff. Easy to work with and always willing to help with tasks.
cons: Parking and commuting to work is a problem. Parking lots are crowded and the bus system is not easy to work with.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: I don't have a lot to say here.  I had a unique job and worked remotely.  Duke is a great University.
cons: The cons of my specific job were that I was working solo and didn't have people to interact with.  That was hard.

job_title: Franklin Center Assistant to A Center in Durham, NC
pros: There are many pro's to working in such a positive environment as this one. Among them are pretty good hours, interesting and varied colleagues, great events, and working on worthwhile projects.
cons: There really aren't too many con's I can think of, unless you don't enjoy working in an academic setting. There may be events that are difficult to schedule or some office politics to deal with.

pros: Benefits are great.  The postdoctoral association at Duke has provided many seminars and workshops to allow you to improve skills necessary to advance to a permanent job.
cons: Parking is in short supply near the research buildings.  As a postdoc at a Heavy R01 university like Duke you are expected to put in long hours and there can be significant sacrifices needed in your family/personal life.

pros: Great people, highly motivated. Duke University's high reputation matters, and everyone works to uphold high standards. Benefits are very comprehensive. Forward-looking and stable environment.
cons: Pay not as good as private sector. But still better than public universities. You know going in that a university doesn't have a bonus plan so there's no upside there.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in North Charleston, SC
pros: Need to continue improve my knowledge through entering in to Post Doc fellow. I want to improve my knowledge through research.
cons: If I am provided this opportunity. I will defiantly will prove myself a good asset for the Organization I will work in near future.

pros: Wonderful people and attitudes from staff and most of the professionals.
cons: Some of the PI's have forgotten that there should be a balance of play and work with the technician level workers.

pros: TIP has been a great program for gifted youth. Helpful resources and challenging program are available.
cons: Threatening culture. Staff overworked. Unclear leadership. Always making irrational changes. Very unhappy place to work.

pros: Nice school, nice place to live in terms of the weather and living cost. People are in general very kind. Of course, you have a lot to do if you are a big basketball fan.
cons: Pay is not that good compared to a lot of other places. Science and Engineering programs here are not matched to the reputation of the school. Summer can be very hot.

pros:
Duke is a great place to work as a student. There are tons of job opportunities on campus. Working as a Circulation Assistant at Perkins Library is typically coveted by both undergraduates and grad students because you basically get paid to work on homework.

Pros
-laid-back environment
-able to do homework at work
-easy work
cons:
-pay was kind of low, but i was a student working part-time anyway
-nothing else really

pros: I was working with a world class scientist as my adviser in Duke. Good salary and reasonable benefit. Staffs in the university are helpful. You can find good daycare for baby.
cons: Parking is limited and quite far away from buildings. The whole university emphasis bio related research too much that other departments get not enough support.

job_title: Network/Systems Analyst II in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great benefits, good work/home balance.
cons: Pay is much lower than private sector. There are no bonus and yearly raises are meager at best.

pros: If you are a student and end up at the desk, you get plenty of chances to work on homework.  There is low pressure on time when shelving and you are free to listen to music.
cons: It is a bit boring and the pay is non-negotiable.

pros: There are opportunities to further your education through employee degree programs and the benefits are very good.The campus is a wonderful environment and the culture is generally supportive of professional development. Additionally, there are very talented students and staff. Definitely a plus when collaboration is needed for project or other types of work.
cons: Work-life was at times challenging, and can be frustrating considering the compensation.

pros: Duke provides pretty good health benefits at a low cost, there are multiple different training courses and classes staff can take
cons: The pay was pretty low and raises were very minimal. Promotions do not exist at Duke. You can work there for 2 years and be great at your job but the only way to move to a higher position is to apply for it.

pros: The tipsters (students) are usually great, intelligent children.
cons:
Where do I start?? Working 12-18 work days for three weeks straight (with one 24 hour day off a week that went from 10AM-10AM) and only a very small salary. Worked out to way less than minimum wage for a high stress job. We had very little actual training. I help run a different summer camp now and we have 30 hours of training. Compared to Duke Tips training which was more like "hey you're here now, lets plan the next three weeks instead of actually train you".  Management was disrespectful and played favorites. We were expected to come up with unique and fun activities with little to no direction or supplies. If we needed supplies, we were usually on a strict budget which I can understand until you remember how extremely expensive this program is and how the kids deserve to have more opportunities for evening activities. The Mental Health Counslelor at our program was never available and when she did speak to students, it was unprofessional and accusatory (as many students told me). Overall the mentality from the upper level staff treated the students like they were suspicious of them or like they were being punished when in reality as a residential staff member it is our job to create a FUN and safe experience outside of class for them. I was also expected to take my 13 thirteen year olds on an off campus activity to somewhere fun and was expected to pay out of pocket for myself wherever they wanted to go. One session they wanted to go to the movies so I had to pay for my own movie ticket. We were told since we led the discussion with our students on where to go then we had to be responsible for paying for ourselves. (the tipsters paid for themselves too).

Lastly, I had to call the Duke TIP employment line with a question about how I was to receive my W2 since I had moved. I was immediately berated and yelled at for no good reason. I was shocked. I am always nice and polite on the phone and I have never, ever been treated that way. The woman on the phone called me entitled and spoiled for simply asking how I was going to get my W2. I truly did not understand how asking a simply question in a polite tone could make someone go off on me like that.The best part? She told me it was coming in the mail when it was actually online through an employment portal.

review_title: Duke treats it's employees with respect and fairness, offering plenty of opportunities for advancement and education
pros:
Great Health Benefits
Tuition breaks for children
Competitive Compensation
Opportunities for Career advancement and education
cons: Payroll is slow and difficult to deal with when you're first starting or when changes occur.  But once things are settled you'll be fine

pros: Duke has great flexible schedules.  Mostly because there are very little deadlines that need to be kept.
cons: Extremely poor leadership in  Information Technology.  Managers have moved up the ladder simply by politics and not by merit.  They care little for their staff and are rarely seen.

pros: The academic reputation of the institution is excellent. The research support services are above average. The campus is physically a nice place to work.
cons: The culture is very arrogant and uncollegial. Anyone not on the tenure track is given little support and treated badly.

pros: Duke provided pretty good facility to nurture young researchers. In general, Duke administration is wonderful to work with. Whenever in need, they will extend their helping hand to you.
cons: There is no significant complain about Duke. Although, Duke being located in north Durham, there is not much thing to do outside of the campus. In some region, safety is a big issue.

review_title: Great place and environment to work. Smart, hard working and highly dedicated faculty, students and researchers.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Durham, NC
pros: Core facilities. Laboratory conditions. Quality of research environment. Access to state pf the art resources. Quality and affordability of life. Beautiful area. Direct connection to clinical research.
cons: Hard to grow as an independent investigator. They do not hire internally

review_title: Top tier, but expect to work for it
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Durham, NC
pros: Top tier people. Many opportunities to seek out funding. Great place to work on latest research.
cons: Not much work life balance, though a good amount of flexibility.  Some pretty unprofessional behavior from tenured faculty (though that's probably standard at most univ)

pros: Company culture & pride, Great Benefits, Large following and Impressive on Resume, Convenient access to highways, Big Company with Growth potential
cons: So many stuffy leaders it is hard to have your voice heard, pay is below average for creatives, great if you want to follow directions and have no creative input.

pros: family community, great benefits, great pay, numerous opportunities, brilliant people, very diverse, they appreciate their employees, great faculty and staff, always part of the team even after leaving
cons: Parking is definitely a con, but that is common with universities.  Parking in the summer is not as bad as it is during the school year.

pros: Great benefits and work life balance, kind coworkers, access to amazing resources, generous compensation. There are bountiful opportunities to meet people doing interesting things outside of your area of expertise.
cons: Some offices are resistant to change--senior leadership (at least in my office/department) could have been less authoritative and more open to new ideas.

pros: Fantastic opportunities to apply technology to different scientific topics and academic domains. Work on unique projects that have a public profile.
cons: Salaries consistently below market, and cost-of-living adjustments haven't kept up, especially in a city where the costs are rising. Benefits packages have many shortcoming, and extended benefits, such as a tuition grants, are so ill-defined it make long-term planning difficult.

pros:
Reasonable pay
Excellent exposure, depending on what department you're working for
Some research labs have good parking, easy access
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy to access salary and benefits
Ridiculously long and boring training to work in medical fields, but that's pretty standard

pros:
Freedom to experiment
Beautiful campus
Hands-off managers in my department
Funding for professional development
cons:
Some co-workers phoning it in
All depends on who your manager is at Duke
Most of the great people leave after a few years
Salary lower than average

pros: Very good benefits and overall working conditions, beautiful location to work in and in a vibrant city like Durham
cons: Non profit organization  means salary is not overly high; slow to latch onto innovations other organizations jump at

review_title: My experience at Duke University was great.
job_title: Associate In Research in Durham, NC
pros: The atmosphere at Duke University is pleasant. The people are extremely nice and I enjoyed working in the Economics department.
cons: My salary was very low for the work I was doing. I felt as though the stress level and technical expertise needed for my position of Associate in Research was higher than my salary warranted.

pros: Benefits are excellent, most everyone is nice and easy to get along with. Beautiful campus.
cons: You pretty much have to work for temporary services to get your foot in the door and then hope that a staff position opens up. And once a staff assistant always a staff assistant. Parking sucks.

pros: Very fun coworkers, was fun working with the kids
cons: The system is very hierarchical, and the higher-ups clearly didn't care about their employees very much. We seemed very expendable. A lot of my coworkers were put on suspension for complaining about our supervisor.
